frameDefinitions: The action of an Agent or the occurrence of a Cause event returns an Entity to an earlier  state of vigor and strength.
An Agent acts so as to cause some process to begin again after an interruption or suspension.
An Agent causes an Explosive device to explode.
An Agent resumes participation in an Activity.
An Agent acts according to a <em>

This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
frameExamples: Falling prices and wireless connectivity have <t>breathed new life</t> into the PDA market.
The two countries <t>revived</t> diplomatic relations after a lull of five years.
Normal Service Will Be <t>Resumed</t> Shortly. CNI
Health authorities say they have put measures into <t>effect</t> in all ports of entry and in centers of provinces.
The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
listRoleDefinitions: The concrete or abstract thing that is brought into an earlier state in which it was more effective and powerful.
The <fen>Agent</fen> puts the <fen>Entity</fen> into a state of renewed vigor.
An event or state whose occurrence brings about the <fen>Entity</fen>'s return to a vigorous state.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the renewal of the <fen>Entity</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the Agent brings about the change in the <fen>Entity</fen>'s state.
A sentient being acts with the intention of causing a process to begin again.
The process which begins again after a suspension.
The period of time during which the process is suspended.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that causes the process to resume. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of Causes.
The time at which the process is restarted.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the <fen>Process</fen> to resume.
The <fen>Agent</fen> detonates the <fen>Explosive</fen>.
The <fen>Explosive</fen> causes damage to surrounding objects when operated by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> detonates the <fen>Explosive</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Agent</fen> detonates the <fen>Explosive</fen>.
The <fen>Activity</fen> which is being resumed by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> who resumes an <fen>Activity</fen> that they were engaged in earlier.
When the Activity is resumed.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Plan</fen> is a goal or purpose that the <fen>Agent</fen> carries out.

The <fen>Agent</fen>, often an institution or governmental organization, puts a <fen>Plan</fen> into effect. The Agent is generally a primary participant in the <fen>Plan</fen>, but a separate <fen>Focal_participant</fen> may be specified.
This role describes the medium through which a plan was executed.  It may occur in the same syntactic position as the Agent.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the Agent puts the <fen>Plan</fen> into effect.

The <fen>Place</fen> at which the <fen>Plan</fen> is or is not operational.

[CHANGE: or, place where agent puts into effect? 2 fes?]

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
listRoleExamples: The reinvigoration <fex>of the tourism</fex> economy is recognised by many as an ambitious but necessary objective.
<fex>We</fex> revitalized the Golden Mountaineer Card, and we gave seniors a prescription drug benefit.
Rock has been rejuvenated creatively and commercially <fex>by hip-hop-inspired rock acts</fex>.
Production was revitalized <fex>last June</fex>.

New York's distinction as America's tax cut leader has revitalized the economy
<fex>in every corner of the state</fex>.
<fex>The driver</fex> restarted the truck after it stalled.
The two countries revived diplomatic relations <fex>after a lull of five years</fex>.
<fex>The spring rains</fex> restarted the flow of the stream.
This state reinstated the death penalty <fex>in 1975</fex>.
The two nations revived relations <fex>in Geneva</fex> during the latest round of talks.
We have renewed <fex>our efforts to gain federal recognition</fex>.
<fex>We</fex> renewed our efforts to get things completed.
The policy will be implemented <fex>by a new computer system</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> responded to the objection convincingly.
Sue answered <fex>Bob</fex> immediately.
<fex>'I can't help you,'</fex> Sue answered.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
Sue answered <fex>the question</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
